My first blog post - Intro to myself and machine learning

Published on Jul 14 2025 ¬∑ personal non-programming non-technical guide-to-machine-learning my-experience-with-machiine-learning-so-far

Who am I anyway?

I‚Äôm Pranav Kumar Sankaranarayanan, a 19 year old student from India, currently persuing my Bachelors in Computer Science at Amrita Vishwavidyapeetham.

I started programming during my 10th class, when I was first introduced to Python. From then I fell in love with that language. I started learning it soo much soo that I started creating machine learning models when I was in 11th class. I learn PyTorch, NumPy, and many related libraries. But I also didn‚Äôt stop there. To be fair to this world of programmers and the highly persuasive programmers on the social media, I also tried various other programming languages, so much so that I couldn‚Äôt even decide my career. But who decides their career in 11th grade right? Right? I too thought so. But just try joining BtechTards discord server once. You will see 16 year old kids making animations using Rust, Manim, and many more. That‚Äôs when I realised that I‚Äôm lacking behind.

So that‚Äôs when I decided to try out everything I could ‚Äî learnt Video editing, audio mixing and mastering, web development (Astro was a part of it too), but Python always found a way to attract me back to it beauty and simplicity.

It‚Äôs almost like seeing the perfect girl in your life. It was just perfect in all ways. But there was a huge cost to pay. Those simplicity and beauty came at a cost of highly competitive and hard career path. I don‚Äôt care what others say ‚Äî people say that you can literally do anything in Python. But nobody does ‚Äî I said it.

Pythong is primarily used for Machine learning and Deep learning. You can‚Äôt convince me otherwise. And agree or not, it is one of the worst career path to choose. Not because its low paying. It is quite the opposite. You can earn millions in that. But its highly unstructured and vast.

Imagine this. You are 5. You are starting to learn Mathematics. You start with learning numbers, then simple operations, then you apply those operations to big numbers. You have a structured pathway to learn it.

But in Machine learning, you simply don‚Äôt. Some people advice you to learn the math behind it:

  • Linear algebra (mostly vectors and scalars, some matrix operations)
  • Some calculus and,
  • Probability & Statistics.

But hey! Then comes another set of people instructing you to not learn the math, but rather the various ways you can implement those math in Python. At first it would sound stupid, how can I learn to use the math that too in a programming language without even knowing how to do it in paper. But when you actually do it, you kinda feel like its the way. And once you have sorted out the math problem, you then come to the biggest problem.

Toolsüõ†Ô∏è.

There are like hundreds of libraries that do the same thing. PyTorch is the same as tensorflow but with enhancements. Nobody know why. Ofcourse there are many advantages, like the ability to employ your CUDA drivers that you might have downloaded with a statistics software to leverage your NVIDIA GPU (if you have one ofc ü§£). But go to an actual machine learning engineer. They would say ‚ÄúI use it because everybody uses it.‚Äù or something like ‚ÄúThats what they instructed me to use.‚Äù

So what is the right way then? Simply put, there isn‚Äôt. But here is the path I followed. And I‚Äôm still following

How to actually become a machine learning enginner

Start of with Math. I would not suggest you to not skip it. Learn just the basics

Linear algebra

Machine learning is essentially manipulating data inside a matrix or a vector. And the math that deals with all this is linear algebra. Ofcourse there is the GOATED Khan Academy.

  1. Vecor and Spaces
  2. Matrices and Matric Transformations

Calculus

Calculus and particularly derivatives and gradients play a key role in the optimization techniques. Starting from the classical minimizer to complex algorithms.

  1. Integrals
  2. Differential Equations
  3. Application of Integrals
  4. Parametric equations, polar coordinates, and vector-valued functions
  5. Series
  6. Gradients

Probability and Statistics

Another essential math tool that you might need is Probability and Statistics. Thought I didn‚Äôt focus much in this, it‚Äôs a good skill to have provided how much ML models are inclined into predictions more than automation these days.

  1. Entire Khan Academy Statistics and probability course.

You can take the parts of this course you think are important. And then do the course challenge

  1. Another niche yet important concept in statistics ‚Äî Bayesian statistics

Once you are strong in all of these, you can start the real fun. Start learning Python. There are literally millions of courses and videos out there. You can choose anything. The key is to be consistent. Choose on course that you are comfortable with and stick to it. The biggest mistake I did was, I kept hopping between different courses. I always had this feeling that ‚ÄúThere might be some other course out there that is better than the current one I‚Äôm learning from.‚Äù

Please please üôèüôè don‚Äôt do that mistake for god‚Äôs sake.

  1. Learn the Basic Syntax and Data Types
    You‚Äôll need to familiarize yourself with Python‚Äôs syntax, variables, data types (integers, floats, strings, lists, dicts), and basic operations (arithmetic, string manipulation, indexing, slicing).
  2. Control Flow
    Understand conditional statements (if, elif, else), loops (for, while), and logical operators (and, or, not). Very important for implementing decision-making and repetition in your code.
  3. Functions and modules
    Learn how to define and use functions to encapsulate reusable blocks of code. Also, you‚Äôll need to understand how to import and utilize modules (libs).
  4. Data Structures and Manipulation
    Get yourself acquainted with fundamental data structures like lists, tuples, sets, and dictionaries. Learn how to manipulate and transform data.
  5. NumPy
    A fundamental library for scientific computing in Python. You will need to gain proficiency in using NumPy arrays for efficient numerical computations.
  6. Pandas
    You will often need Pandas DataFrames to clean, transform, filter, aggregate, and analyze your datasets.
  7. Plotting and Data Visualization
    Become familiar with libraries such as Matplotlib and Seaborn for creating plots, charts, and visualization. Not strictly necessary, but recommended.

Once you are confident in the language, it‚Äôs fairly simple to get started with machine learning concepts, which I will cover in further blogs. Until then see ya, and enjoy your life üòÉüòÉ.
